template.name: Cisco IOS by SNMP
template.description:
Template Cisco IOS Software releases 12.2(3.5) or later
MIBs used: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB IF-MIB EtherLike-MIB HOST-RESOURCES-MIB SNMPv2-MIB CISCO-ENVMON-MIB CISCO-PROCESS-MIB ENTITY-MIB
Known Issues:
Description: no if(in|out)(Errors|Discards) are available for vlan ifType Version: IOS for example: 12.1(22)EA11, 15.4(3)M2 Device: C2911, C7600
Generated by official Zabbix template tool "Templator"

trigger.name: Cisco IOS: Unavailable by ICMP ping
trigger.description: Last three attempts returned timeout. Please check device connectivity.

trigger.expression: min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)<100
trigger.name: Cisco IOS: High ICMP ping loss

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Unavailable by ICMP ping

trigger.name: Cisco IOS: High ICMP ping response time
trigger.description: Average ICMP response time is too high.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: High ICMP ping loss
dependency.expression: min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)<100

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Unavailable by ICMP ping

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk EtherLike-MIB interfaces
item.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with `up(1)` Operational Status are discovered.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk network interfaces
item.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk fans
item.description: Discovering system fans.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk PSUs
item.description: The table of power supply status maintained by the environmental monitor card.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk temperature sensors
item.description: Discovery of ciscoEnvMonTemperatureTable (ciscoEnvMonTemperatureDescr), a table of ambient temperature status maintained by the environmental monitor.

item.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
item.description: The item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

item.name: System contact details
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk system CPUs
item.description: If your IOS device has several CPUs, you must use CISCO-PROCESS-MIB and its object cpmCPUTotal5minRev from the table called cpmCPUTotalTable, indexed with cpmCPUTotalIndex. This table allows CISCO-PROCESS-MIB to keep CPU statistics for different physical entities in the router, like different CPU chips, group of CPUs, or CPUs in different modules/cards. In case of a single CPU, cpmCPUTotalTable has only one entry.

item.name: System description
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Hardware model name
item.description: MIB: ENTITY-MIB

item.name: Hardware serial number
item.description: MIB: ENTITY-MIB

trigger.expression: last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber,#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber,#2) and length(last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber))>0
trigger.name: Cisco IOS: Device has been replaced
trigger.event_name: Cisco IOS: Device has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger.description: Device serial number has changed. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk entity serial numbers
item.description: MIB: ENTITY-MIB Entity Serial Numbers Discovery.

item.name: Uptime (hardware)
item.description: MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB The amount of time since this host was last initialized. Note that this is different from sysUpTime in the SNMPv2-MIB [RFC1907] because sysUpTime is the uptime of the network management portion of the system.

item.name: System location
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB Physical location of the node (e.g., `equipment room`, `3rd floor`). If not provided, the value is a zero-length string.

item.name: System name
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

trigger.expression: last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name,#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name,#2) and length(last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name))>0
trigger.name: Cisco IOS: System name has changed
trigger.event_name: Cisco IOS: System name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: The name of the system has changed. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

item.name: Uptime (network)
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB Time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

item.name: System object ID
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity. This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed. For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

item.name: Operating system
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB

trigger.expression: last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.sw.os[sysDescr.0],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.sw.os[sysDescr.0],#2) and length(last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.sw.os[sysDescr.0]))>0
trigger.name: Cisco IOS: Operating system description has changed
trigger.description: The description of the operating system has changed. Possible reasons are that the system has been updated or replaced. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: System name has changed
dependency.expression: last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name,#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name,#2) and length(last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.name))>0

item.name: Cisco IOS: SNMP walk memory
item.description: MIB: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB Discovery of ciscoMemoryPoolTable, a table of memory pool monitoring entries. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html.

item.name: SNMP agent availability
item.description: Availability of SNMP checks on the host. The value of this item corresponds to availability icons in the host list. Possible values: 0 - not available 1 - available 2 - unknown

trigger.name: Cisco IOS: No SNMP data collection
trigger.description: SNMP is not available for polling. Please check device connectivity and SNMP settings.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Unavailable by ICMP ping

discovery_rule.name: CPU Discovery
discovery_rule.description: If your IOS device has several CPUs, you must use CISCO-PROCESS-MIB and its object cpmCPUTotal5minRev from the table called cpmCPUTotalTable, indexed with cpmCPUTotalIndex. This table allows CISCO-PROCESS-MIB to keep CPU statistics for different physical entities in the router, like different CPU chips, group of CPUs, or CPUs in different modules/cards. In case of a single CPU, cpmCPUTotalTable has only one entry.

item_prototype.name: #{#SNMPINDEX}: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB The cpmCPUTotal5minRev MIB object provides a more accurate view of the performance of the router over time than the MIB objects cpmCPUTotal1minRev and cpmCPUTotal5secRev . These MIB objects are not accurate because they look at CPU at one minute and five second intervals, respectively. These MIBs enable you to monitor the trends and plan the capacity of your network. The recommended baseline rising threshold for cpmCPUTotal5minRev is 90 percent. Depending on the platform, some routers that run at 90 percent, for example, 2500s, can exhibit performance degradation versus a high-end router, for example, the 7500 series, which can operate fine. Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15215-collect-cpu-util-snmp.html

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: #{#SNMPINDEX}: High CPU utilization
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: #{#SNMPINDEX}: High CPU utilization (over {$CPU.UTIL.CRIT}% for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

trigger_prototype.expression: last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber[entPhysicalSerialNum.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber[entPhysicalSerialNum.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2) and length(last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.serialnumber[entPhysicalSerialNum.{#SNMPINDEX}]))>0
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#ENT_NAME}: Device has been replaced
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: {#ENT_NAME}: Device has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger_prototype.description: Device serial number has changed. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

discovery_rule.name: FAN Discovery
discovery_rule.description: The table of fan status maintained by the environmental monitor.

trigger_prototype.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:\"critical\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:\"shutdown\"}")=1
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Fan is in critical state

trigger_prototype.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_WARN_STATUS:\"warning\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_WARN_STATUS:\"notFunctioning\"}")=1
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Fan is in warning state

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Fan is in critical state
dependency.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:\"critical\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.fan.status[ciscoEnvMonFanState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:\"shutdown\"}")=1

discovery_rule.name: Memory Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of ciscoMemoryPoolTable, a table of memory pool monitoring entries. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Free memory
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently unused on the managed device. Note that the sum of ciscoMemoryPoolUsed and ciscoMemoryPoolFree is the total amount of memory in the pool Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Used memory
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-MEMORY-POOL-MIB Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently in use by applications on the managed device. Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15216-contiguous-memory.html

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: High memory utilization
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: High memory utilization (>{$MEMORY.UTIL.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The system is running out of free memory.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifInOctets. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifOutOctets.Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n`, then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000` to `n+499,999`. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The current operational state of the interface. - The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed - If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2) - If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic - It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection) - It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state - It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

trigger_prototype.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
This trigger expression works as follows: 1. It can be triggered if the operations status is down. 2. `{$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1` - a user can redefine the context macro to "0", marking this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. `last(/TEMPLATE_NAME/METRIC,#1)<>last(/TEMPLATE_NAME/METRIC,#2)` - the trigger fires only if the operational status was up to (1) sometime before (so, does not fire for "eternal off" interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - it will not fire again on the next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The type of interface. Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA), through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototype.expression: change(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])<0 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0 and ( last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=6 or last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=7 or last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=11 or last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=62 or last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=69 or last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=117 ) and (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: (change(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2)>0) or (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

trigger_prototype.expression: (avg(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) or avg(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])) and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: avg(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) and avg(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage (>{$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: The utilization of the network interface is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

trigger_prototype.expression: min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.in.errors[ifInErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} or min(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.out.errors[ifOutErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: max(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.in.errors[ifInErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8 and max(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.out.errors[ifOutErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate (>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: It recovers when it is below 80% of the `{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}` threshold.

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

discovery_rule.name: EtherLike-MIB Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with `up(1)` Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototype.description: MIB: EtherLike-MIB The current mode of operation of the MAC entity. `unknown` indicates that the current duplex mode could not be determined. Management control of the duplex mode is accomplished through the MAU MIB. When an interface does not support autonegotiation or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the duplex mode is controlled using `ifMauDefaultType`. When autonegotiation is supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled using `ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits`. In either case, the currently operating duplex mode in reflected both in this object and in `ifMauType`. Note that this object provides redundant information with `ifMauType`. Normally, redundant objects are discouraged. However, in this instance, it allows a management application to determine the duplex status of an interface without having to know every possible value of `ifMauType`. This was felt to be sufficiently valuable to justify the redundancy. Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototype.description: Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling.

discovery_rule.name: PSU Discovery
discovery_rule.description: The table of power supply status maintained by the environmental monitor card.

trigger_prototype.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_CRIT_STATUS:\"critical\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_CRIT_STATUS:\"shutdown\"}")=1
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Power supply is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Please check the power supply unit for errors

trigger_prototype.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_WARN_STATUS:\"warning\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_WARN_STATUS:\"notFunctioning\"}")=1
trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Power supply is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Please check the power supply unit for errors

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: {#SENSOR_INFO}: Power supply is in critical state
dependency.expression: count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_CRIT_STATUS:\"critical\"}")=1 or count(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/sensor.psu.status[ciscoEnvMonSupplyState.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1,"eq","{$PSU_CRIT_STATUS:\"shutdown\"}")=1

discovery_rule.name: Temperature Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of ciscoEnvMonTemperatureTable (ciscoEnvMonTemperatureDescr), a table of ambient temperature status maintained by the environmental monitor.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-ENVMON-MIB The current state of the test point being instrumented.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-ENVMON-MIB The current measurement of the test point being instrumented.

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is too low
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is too low: <{$TEMP_CRIT_LOW:"{#SNMPVALUE}"}

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above critical threshold
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above critical threshold: >{$TEMP_CRIT:"{#SNMPVALUE}"}
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

trigger_prototype.name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above warning threshold
trigger_prototype.event_name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above warning threshold: >{$TEMP_WARN:"{#SNMPVALUE}"}
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: {#SNMPVALUE}: Temperature is above critical threshold

macro.description: Warning threshold of ICMP packet loss in %.
Warning threshold of the average ICMP response time in seconds.
Warning threshold of error packet rate. Can be used with interface name as context.
Used as a threshold in the interface utilization trigger.
Link status trigger will be fired only for interfaces where the context macro equals "1".
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used for network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Filters out `loopbacks`, `nulls`, docker `veth` links and `docker0 bridge` by default.
Used for network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Used in network interface discovery rule filters.
Time interval for the SNMP availability trigger.

trigger.expression: (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])>0 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])<10m) or (last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])=0 and last(/Cisco IOS by SNMP/system.net.uptime[sysUpTime.0])<10m)
trigger.name: Cisco IOS: Host has been restarted

dependency.name: Cisco IOS: No SNMP data collection
